questions.text:
A 50-year-old man comes to the physician for his annual health maintenance examination. The patient feels well. He has a history of hypertension, for which he currently takes lisinopril. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. He drinks five to six beers on weekends. He is 181 cm tall (5 ft 11 in) and weighs 80 kg (176 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2. His pulse is 75/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory studies show:


Total cholesterol
263 mg/dL


High-density lipoprotein cholesterol
36 mg/dL


Triglycerides
180 mg/dL


In addition to dietary and lifestyle modification, administration of which of the following agents is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B3 (niacin) has mild LDL-lowering effects and is not recommended as a first-line drug for patients with high LDL-C levels. Niacin can be used in the treatment of severe hypertriglyceridemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Ezetimibe, a cholesterol absorption inhibitor, is a second-line lipid-lowering agent that is reserved for patients who do not tolerate the first-line drug or have contraindications for it. It may also be administered to augment the effect of the first-line drug if it does not sufficiently lower LDL levels.

C) INCORRECT:

PCSK9 inhibitors such as alirocumab and evolocumab are effective in lowering LDL levels. They are used as second-line lipid-lowering agents and can be considered if treatment goals are not met with first-line therapy.

D) CORRECT:

HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors, more commonly referred to as statins, are the first-line treatment for dyslipidemia. According to the 2018 AHA/ACC guidelines, adults with an LDL-cholesterol concentration ≥ 190 mg/dL should be started on statin therapy. Statins are the most effective drug for reducing LDL levels and also improving HDL and triglyceride levels.

E) INCORRECT:

Bile acid resins such as cholestyramine can be used as an adjunct to first-line therapy but are not recommended as monotherapy for dyslipidemia. Bile acid resins only minimally lower LDL, and the gastrointestinal side effects (nausea, bloating, cramping) and increase in liver enzymes often necessitate discontinuation of treatment.

F) INCORRECT:

PPARα activators, which are more commonly referred to as fibrates (e.g., bezafibrate, fenofibrate), are most commonly used in the treatment of hypertriglyceridemia. They are not recommended as LDL-lowering agents. Another lipid-lowering agent with a more potent effect on LDL levels is preferred at this point.
questions.hint: To calculate LDL, use the following equation: LDL (mg/dL) = total cholesterol - HDL - (triglycerides/5), where “triglycerides/5” represents VLDL. In this patient, LDL = 263 mg/dL - 36 mg/dL - (180 mg/dL/5) = 191 mg/dL. Given this patient's age, history of hypertension, and LDL level, he is at elevated risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD).

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 4-month history of chest pain that occurs on exertion. The pain is dull, and she has retrosternal pressure when she walks up the stairs to her apartment on the fifth floor. The pain disappears shortly after stopping for one minute. She has hypertension, for which she takes lisinopril and metoprolol daily. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is 158 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 82 kg (180 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. Her pulse is 72/min and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Fasting lipid studies show:


Total cholesterol
196 mg/dL


LDL
110 mg/dL


HDL
50 mg/dL


A resting ECG shows no abnormalities. A week after uneventful initiation of aspirin, the patient is started on atorvastatin. This patient is most likely to develop which of the following adverse effects?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bloating is a common side effect of bile acid resins such as cholestyramine and colestipol. Bile acid resins can also cause diarrhea by inhibiting the reabsorption of bile acids (interruption of enterohepatic circulation). Bloating is not a common adverse effect of statins.

B) INCORRECT:

Although muscle aches (myalgias), including soreness, stiffness, and/or cramps, are a more common adverse effect of statin administration (statin myopathy), myositis, which manifests with elevated serum creatinine kinase activity, occurs in only < 0.5% of patients taking statins. Another rare but serious potential side effect of statin administration (esp. when taken in conjunction with fibrates) is rhabdomyolysis.

C) CORRECT:

Elevated transaminases occur in up to 3% of patients receiving statin therapy. This asymptomatic side effect typically resolves spontaneously over time. However, in very rare cases, overt hepatotoxicity can occur, resulting in transaminitis (> 10 times the upper normal limit of transaminases).

D) INCORRECT:

Cholelithiasis is a common complication of medical treatment with fibrates or bile acid resins (bile acid sequestrants), as well as rapid weight loss (e.g., after bariatric surgery). While statins do change the lipid composition of the blood, they are not known to cause adverse effects related to bile.

E) INCORRECT:

Flushing as a result of peripheral vasodilation is a common side effect of nicotinic acid (vitamin B3) due to increased synthesis of prostaglandins D2 and E2. Other side effects include hyperglycemia and hyperuricemia. Statins are not known to cause flushing.
questions.hint: Administration of statins and the subsequent changes in lipid components in cell membranes can cause a mostly asymptomatic, and usually transient, side effect.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has hyperlipidemia and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He takes medium-dose simvastatin and metformin. Four months ago, fasting serum studies showed an LDL-cholesterol of 136 mg/dL and his medications were adjusted. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, there is generalized weakness of the proximal muscles. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Fasting serum studies show:


Total cholesterol
154 mg/dL


HDL-cholesterol
45 mg/dL


LDL-cholesterol
81 mg/dL


Triglycerides
138 mg/dL


Glucose
94 mg/dL


Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL


Creatine kinase
260 U/L


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient's hyperlipidemia?

choices.text: Discontinue simvastatin, start pravastatin in 3 weeks
Discontinue simvastatin, start niacin in 3 weeks

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

After discontinuation of simvastatin for a period of 2–4 weeks and once symptoms have resolved, the patient should begin treatment with low-dose pravastatin (or fluvastatin). These statins have been shown to have the lowest risk of muscular side effects. If symptoms of myopathy do not occur, the dose can be adjusted to achieve the goals outlined in the guidelines for lipid-lowering therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Niacin is used in the treatment of dyslipidemia but is mostly recommended for severe hypertriglyceridemia, not for hypercholesterolemia. Also, combining niacin with statin therapy increases the rate of adverse effects such as myopathy. Finally, niacin should be avoided in patients with diabetes mellitus because of the risk of worsening glycemic control.

C) INCORRECT:

Bile acid resins (i.e., colestipol, cholestyramine) are among the available second-line treatments for dyslipidemia, but they are generally poorly tolerated due to gastrointestinal side effects (e.g., bloating, constipation). They are most effective in combination with statin therapy rather than administered as a monotherapy. Different lipid-lowering agents should be considered.

D) INCORRECT:

Fibrates (e.g., bezafibrate, fenofibrate, gemfibrozil) are used in the treatment of dyslipidemia. However, fibrates are no longer recommended as LDL-lowering therapy; they are mostly used for the treatment of severe hypertriglyceridemia. Furthermore, fibrates are also associated with an increased risk of myopathy, especially if combined with statins.

E) INCORRECT:

Fibrates (e.g., bezafibrate, fenofibrate, gemfibrozil) are used in the treatment of dyslipidemia. However, fibrates are no longer recommended as LDL-lowering therapy; they are mostly used for the treatment of severe hypertriglyceridemia. Furthermore, fibrates are also associated with an increased risk of myopathy.

F) INCORRECT:

While increasing the dose of this patient's statin medication may further lower LDL levels, this would also likely worsen his statin-associated myopathy. He should be started on a different pharmacologic regimen.

G) INCORRECT:

While a combination of statin therapy and colestipol (instead of statin monotherapy) can be used to further reduce LDL levels, the continuation of simvastatin would not be appropriate in a patient with evidence of statin-associated myopathy.

H) INCORRECT:

Niacin is used in the treatment of dyslipidemia but is mostly recommended for severe hypertriglyceridemia, not for hypercholesterolemia. Also, niacin should be avoided in patients with diabetes mellitus because of the risk of worsening glycemic control.
questions.hint: This patient presents with generalized weakness and an elevated serum creatine kinase (CK) activity. Given the recent change in his medications (presumably an increase in simvastatin dosage), these features suggest statin-associated myopathy.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man comes to the physician for a health maintenance examination. He feels well. He is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum lipid studies show:


Total cholesterol
280 mg/dL



HDL-cholesterol
30 mg/dL



LDL-cholesterol
195 mg/dL



Triglycerides
275 mg/dL



Treatment with atorvastatin and cholestyramine is initiated. Which of the following changes is most likely induced by both agents?

choices.text: Decreased hepatic de novo cholesterol synthesis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased lipoprotein lipase activity is an effect of fibrates. This group of drugs activates the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (PPAR-α), which increases lipoprotein lipase activity, causing LDL and triglycerides to degrade more rapidly. Neither atorvastatin nor cholestyramine has an effect on lipoprotein lipase activity.

B) CORRECT:

Increased LDL receptor expression is an effect of both atorvastatin and cholestyramine use. Atorvastatin inhibits intrahepatic cholesterol biosynthesis, which leads to a compensatory upregulation of LDL receptor expression. Cholestyramine binds bile acids in the intestine and thereby reduces enterohepatic bile acid circulation, which is compensated for by increased hepatic bile acid synthesis. Since cholesterol is needed as the precursor to bile acids, LDL receptor expression is raised in order to enhance cholesterol uptake. Combination therapy with statins and bile acid resins has a stronger hypolipidemic effect than treatment with either drug alone (synergism).

C) INCORRECT:

Increased hepatic bile salt synthesis from cholesterol is an effect of cholestyramine only. Synthesis is enhanced as a compensatory mechanism due to the increased excretion of bile acids induced by this drug.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased hepatic de novo cholesterol synthesis via inhibition of its rate-limiting step (conversion of HMG-CoA to mevalonate) is an effect of atorvastatin only.

E) INCORRECT:

HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors (e.g., atorvastatin) inhibit cholesterol synthesis and would, therefore, decrease rather than increase hepatic cholesterol levels. Therapy with bile acid resins such as cholestyramine would upregulate hepatic cholesterol uptake but hepatic cholesterol levels usually do not increase significantly because bile acid synthesis from cholesterol is also increased. Bile acid resins would upregulate the synthesis of triglyceride-rich VLDL, resulting in slightly increased triglyceride levels in the liver and serum.
questions.hint: Atorvastatin is an HMG-CoA reductase inhibitor and cholestyramine is a bile acid resin.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of severe muscle aches and fatigue for 3 days. Last week he was diagnosed with atypical pneumonia and treated with clarithromycin. He has hyperlipidemia for which he takes lovastatin. Physical examination shows generalized tenderness of the proximal muscles in the upper and lower extremities. Serum studies show an elevated creatine kinase concentration. This patient's current symptoms are most likely caused by inhibition of which of the following hepatic enzymes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The hepatic cytochrome P-450 enzyme CYP2E1 metabolizes alcohols such as ethanol and is involved in the conversion of ethanol to acetaldehyde and subsequently to acetate. It is inhibited by disulfiram and metronidazole. Disulfiram-like reactions can occur due to combined intake of alcohol and metronidazole via interaction with CYP2E1. Statins, including lovastatin, are metabolized by a different hepatic cytochrome P-450 enzyme.

B) INCORRECT:

The hepatic cytochrome P-450 enzyme CYP2D6 metabolizes certain antipsychotics (haloperidol), several beta-blockers (metoprolol), SSRIs, SNRIs, and SSNRIs (e.g., fluoxetine, fluvoxamine, venlafaxine), and antiarrhythmics (flecainide). Inhibitors of CYP2D6 such as amiodarone, metoclopramide, and quinidine can cause these drugs to become toxic. Statins, including lovastatin, are metabolized by a different hepatic cytochrome P-450 enzyme.

C) CORRECT:

The risk of statin-induced toxic myopathy increases with the addition of cytochrome CYP3A4 inhibitors, which include the macrolides clarithromycin and erythromycin (not azithromycin). Other common CYP3A4 inhibitors include amiodarone, antifungals (azoles, e.g., itraconazole), several anti-HIV medications, histamine H2 receptor antagonists (e.g., cimetidine), and grapefruit juice. Lipophilic statins such as simvastatin, atorvastatin, and lovastatin have a higher propensity to cause myopathy than do hydrophilic agents (pravastatin, rosuvastatin), which are not significantly metabolized by CYP3A4. CYP3A4 is involved in the metabolism of > 60% of drugs, and inhibition of this enzyme can lead to an increased risk of drug toxicity, as seen in this case.

See “Cytochrome P450 substrates, inhibitors, and inducers” table.

D) INCORRECT:

The hepatic cytochrome P-450 enzyme CYP2C9 metabolizes warfarin. The CYP2C9 and VKORC1 genotypes are the most important known genetic determinants of warfarin dosing. Patients with VKORC1 polymorphisms require an adjusted dose of warfarin to achieve an anticoagulant effect. Clinical testing for individual polymorphisms is available but has not been convincingly shown to lead to improved clinical outcomes. Statins, including lovastatin, are metabolized by a different hepatic cytochrome P-450 enzyme.

E) INCORRECT:

The hepatic cytochrome P-450 enzyme CYP1A2 metabolizes theophylline, acetaminophen, caffeine, clozapine, haloperidol, and olanzapine. It can be induced by smoking and inhibited by quinolones such as ciprofloxacin. Statins, including lovastatin, are metabolized by a different hepatic cytochrome P-450 enzyme.

F) INCORRECT:

The hepatic cytochrome P-450 enzyme CYP2C19 metabolizes omeprazole, diazepam, citalopram, and clopidogrel. It is inhibited by certain antifungals (fluconazole) and cimetidine. It is induced by rifampin and St. John's Wort. Statins, including lovastatin, are metabolized by a different hepatic cytochrome P-450 enzyme.
questions.hint: Use of clarithromycin to inhibit this hepatic cytochrome P-450 enzyme, which is involved in the metabolism of ≥ 50% of all drugs, has decreased the clearance of lovastatin, resulting in statin myopathy.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for an annual health maintenance examination. He has a history of stable angina, gout, and hypertension. His medications include lisinopril and aspirin. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. He drinks 5–6 beers on the weekends. His blood pressure is 150/85 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show a total cholesterol of 276 mg/dL with an elevated low-density lipoprotein (LDL) concentration and low high-density lipoprotein (HDL) concentration. Administration of which of the following agents is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B3 (niacin) is a lipid-lowering agent synthesized from tryptophan that decreases hepatic VLDL synthesis and inhibits the activity of hormone-sensitive lipase. It increases HDL levels and, to a lesser degree, reduces triglyceride and LDL synthesis. However, it is not considered a first-line monotherapy in patients with hyperlipidemia and it is not recommended in patients with gout because of the associated risk of hyperuricemia.

B) CORRECT:

HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors, more commonly referred to as statins, are the first-line treatment for hyperlipidemia. Statins inhibit cholesterol synthesis in the liver by inhibiting the conversion of HMG-CoA to mevalonate. Statins are the most effective drug for reducing LDL levels, and they also increase HDL and lower triglyceride levels. Common side effects of HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors include elevated LFTs and myalgias (especially when used concomitantly with fibrates).

C) INCORRECT:

Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (PPAR-α) activators are more commonly referred to as fibrates (e.g., bezafibrate, fenofibrate). The activation of PPAR-α increases lipoprotein lipase production, fatty acid uptake, and oxidation as well as HDL synthesis. Fibrates are most effective at decreasing triglyceride levels and increasing HDL levels and only have a mild effect on LDL levels. For this reason, fibrates would not be recommended as monotherapy in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Cholesterol absorption inhibitors like ezetimibe decrease LDL by inhibiting cholesterol absorption at the brush borders of the small intestine. However, ezetimibe is considered a second-line lipid-lowering agent. It is reserved for patients who do not tolerate the first-line drug and would not be the first choice for this patient. Side effects of ezetimibe include diarrhea and increased LFTs.

E) INCORRECT:

PCSK9 inhibitors such as alirocumab and evolocumab work by inhibiting the degradation of LDL receptors, which decreases circulating LDL levels. However, they are currently only recommended as an adjunct treatment in patients in whom first-line therapy has failed. Side effects include myalgias, delirium, and cognitive impairment.

F) INCORRECT:

Bile acid resins such as cholestyramine lower plasma LDL cholesterol levels by binding to bile acid and preventing its reabsorption in the gastrointestinal tract, thereby increasing intestinal LDL losses (which is bound to bile salts). Bile acid resins are not considered a first-line therapy for hyperlipidemia because of their gastrointestinal side effects (e.g., diarrhea) and the fact they lower LDL only minimally.
questions.hint: This patient has hyperlipidemia and a history that suggests coronary artery disease (stable angina).

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man comes to the office as a new patient. He feels well. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. Routine colonoscopy screening from 2 months ago showed diverticulosis. His maternal aunt died from myocardial infarction at the age of 63 years. He does not smoke cigarettes and drinks three to four 12-oz beers weekly. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. His blood pressure is 124/68 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
15.2 g/dL


Leukocyte count
6000/mm3



Hemoglobin A1C

6.2%


Serum



Total cholesterol
185 mg/dL


HDL cholesterol
45 mg/dL


LDL cholesterol
122 mg/dL


Triglycerides
140 mg/dL


The patient's estimated 10-year risk of cardiovascular disease is 9.1%. In addition to counseling on lifestyle modifications, which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Low-dose aspirin therapy is indicated for patients who have ASCVD (for secondary prevention) and can be considered for patients aged 40–59 years with a 10-year ASCVD risk ≥ 10% and a low risk of bleeding (for primary prevention). At this time, a different drug should be prescribed for this patient who does not yet have ASCVD but has an estimated 10-year ASCVD risk of 9.1%.

B) CORRECT:

The indications for statins for primary prevention of ASCVD vary slightly between guidelines. The American College of Cardiology (ACC) and the American Heart Association (AHA) recommend initiating statin therapy (e.g., atorvastatin, rosuvastatin) in patients 40–75 years of age with T2DM regardless of their 10-year ASCVD risk. The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) considers it beneficial to initiate statin therapy in patients with ≥ 1 modifiable traditional ASCVD risk factor (e.g., diabetes) and a 10-year ASCVD risk of ≥ 7.5%. According to both guidelines, there is a benefit to initiating statin therapy in this patient. See the “Indications for statins for primary ASCVD prevention” table.

For reference, see the 2019 ACC/AHA guidelines https://www.ahajournals.org/doi/10.1161/CIR.0000000000000678 and the USPSTF recommendations https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2795521.

C) INCORRECT:

Dapagliflozin is an oral antidiabetic agent that can be added to the drug regimen of a patient with T2DM if monotherapy with metformin has not achieved the HbA1C target of < 7%. This patient, however, has good glycemic control (HbA1C of 6.2%) on metformin alone and, thus, does not require a second antidiabetic drug.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients 40–75 years of age with T2DM and a 10-year ASCVD risk ≥ 7.5% should be prescribed a specific drug for health maintenance.

E) INCORRECT:

Niacin is used in the treatment of hypertriglyceridemia, which this patient does not have. In addition, niacin should be avoided in patients with diabetes since it can negatively impact glycemic control. A different drug should be prescribed to this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Ezetimibe is a second-line lipid-lowering agent that can be used for additional ASCVD risk reduction in patients who do not achieve target LDL reduction with the maximally tolerated dose of first-line therapy. This patient's LDL cholesterol is within the reference range.
questions.hint: This patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and an intermediate atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk (7.5%–20%) requires intervention for primary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD).

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes presents for follow-up. In the 6 months since her last visit, she has lost 4.5 kg of body weight through diet and exercise. She currently takes metformin 1000 mg twice daily, lisinopril 20 mg daily, and a multivitamin.
Her blood pressure is 123/74 mm Hg, and her BMI is 22. The rest of her physical examination is unremarkable.
A fasting lipid panel reveals the following results:



Patient value


Total cholesterol (mg/dL)
189


LDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
95


HDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
43


Triglycerides (mg/dL)
255


Liver function test results are within normal limits, and the patient’s glycated hemoglobin level is 6.3% (reference range, 4.3–5.6). She has no other identifiable cardiovascular risk factors.
Which one of the following treatments is recommended to minimize this patient’s long-term cardiovascular risk?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Icosapent ethyl effectively reduces triglyceride concentrations, especially in individuals with severe hypertriglyceridemia (>500 mg/dL). Studies have shown cardiovascular benefit when icosapent ethyl is added to a statin in patients with hypertriglyceridemia who are at high cardiovascular risk (due to established ASCVD or to type 2 diabetes with at least one additional ASCVD risk factor). Current guidelines therefore suggest considering icosapent ethyl as an addition to a statin in this patient population. However, starting a statin should take precedence.

B) INCORRECT:

Pravastatin 10 mg daily is considered a low-intensity statin and so would not be an appropriate choice in this patient with type 2 diabetes.

C) INCORRECT:

Nicotinic acid and fibrates have not been consistently shown to lower cardiovascular risk and are generally reserved for patients with a severely elevated triglyceride level or a very low HDL-cholesterol level.

D) INCORRECT:

Nicotinic acid and fibrates have not been consistently shown to lower cardiovascular risk and are generally reserved for patients with a severely elevated triglyceride level or a very low HDL-cholesterol level.

E) CORRECT:

Current cholesterol treatment guidelines from the American College of Cardiology (ACC) and the American Heart Association (AHA) outline four “statin benefit” groups for whom atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk reduction clearly outweighs the risk for adverse events. One of those groups is patients aged 40 to 75 years with diabetes mellitus, regardless of their estimated risk for ASCVD. These patients should receive at least a moderate-intensity statin (atorvastatin 10–20 mg daily, rosuvastatin 5–10 mg daily, simvastatin 20–40 mg daily, pravastatin 40–80 mg daily, or lovastatin 40–80 mg daily). If they have multiple ASCVD risk factors, they should receive a high-intensity statin, such as rosuvastatin 20–40 mg daily or atorvastatin 40–80 mg daily, with the goal of reducing LDL-cholesterol levels by ≥50% to a target LDL-cholesterol level of <70 mg/dL. This patient should receive a moderate-intensity statin.

Key learning point: Regardless of estimated risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, primary prevention in patients aged 40 to 75 years with type 2 diabetes should include at least moderate-intensity statin therapy.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease and hypertension returns for a blood-pressure check. His current blood pressure is 156/82 mm Hg. Several weeks ago, he started taking hydrochlorothiazide at a dose of 25 mg daily. His other medications are aspirin 81 mg daily, carvedilol 25 mg twice daily, and simvastatin 40 mg daily. His kidney function and potassium levels have been normal.
Which one of the following antihypertensive drugs can be added safely and effectively to this patient’s current medication regimen?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Use of simvastatin has been associated with an increased risk for myopathy, and several common medications increase plasma levels of this drug. Medications that are contraindicated in simvastatin users include ketoconazole, erythromycin, protease inhibitors, gemfibrozil, cyclosporine, and danazol. Verapamil, diltiazem, amiodarone, and dronedarone can be used safely only when a patient’s simvastatin dose is kept at or below 10 mg daily. Amlodipine can be added when the simvastatin dose is no more than 20 mg. Ramipril can be added to a medication regimen that includes daily simvastatin at 40 mg.

Key learning point: Medications such as verapamil or diltiazem limit the maximum daily dose of simvastatin that a patient can safely take to 10 mg.

B) INCORRECT:

Use of simvastatin has been associated with an increased risk for myopathy, and several common medications increase plasma levels of this drug. Verapamil, diltiazem, amiodarone, and dronedarone can be used safely only when a patient’s simvastatin dose is kept at or below 10 mg daily.

C) INCORRECT:

Use of simvastatin has been associated with an increased risk for myopathy, and several common medications increase plasma levels of this drug. Verapamil, diltiazem, amiodarone, and dronedarone can be used safely only when a patient’s simvastatin dose is kept at or below 10 mg daily.

D) INCORRECT:

Use of simvastatin has been associated with an increased risk for myopathy, and several common medications increase plasma levels of this drug. Amlodipine can be added when the simvastatin dose is no more than 20 mg.

E) INCORRECT:

Alpha-blockers, such as doxazosin, are not recommended as second-line antihypertensive therapy, as they have been associated with an increased incidence of cardiovascular events.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman with documented coronary disease reports a one-month history of diffuse muscle aches. She also notes an increase in fatigue and an inability to exercise as much as she would like. She has had no fevers, chills, joint swelling, or recent trauma.
Treatment with atorvastatin 40 mg daily, aspirin, and metoprolol was initiated 6 months ago after she was diagnosed with a non-Q-wave myocardial infarction.
Her vital signs are normal, and she has no erythema, rashes, or joint swelling. Her muscle strength is 5 out of 5 in all extremities. Her muscles are mildly tender to palpation.
The results of her liver function tests are within normal limits.
Other laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


LDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
83
<130


HDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
39
≥46


Triglycerides (mg/dL)
190
<150


Total cholesterol (mg/dL)
160
125–200


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.1
0.6–1.1


Creatine kinase (U/liter)
230
40–150


Thyroid-stimulating hormone (μU/mL)
2.5
0.5–4.7


25-hydroxyvitamin D (ng/mL)
32
30–80


Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Continue atorvastatin at the current dose
Stop atorvastatin, then start niacin when symptoms have resolved
Stop atorvastatin, then start rosuvastatin when symptoms have resolved
Stop atorvastatin, then start ezetimibe when symptoms have resolved
Stop atorvastatin, then remeasure lipid levels in 2 months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If the symptoms are mild but interfering with activity and quality of life, and the creatine kinase level is ≤5 times the upper limit of normal, a reasonable first step is to lower the dose or switch to another statin, rather than continuing at the current dose.

B) INCORRECT:

The evidence supporting secondary preventive benefit is more robust for statins than for other lipid-lowering drugs; hence, switching to another drug class such as niacin is a less desirable initial approach in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Patients taking statins are at risk for myopathy, which is characterized by myalgias and/or muscle weakness, particularly of the upper limbs or trunk. In a patient who has myalgias, creatine kinase, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels should be checked, because the myalgias may be linked to conditions unrelated to statin use, such as thyroid disease or vitamin D deficiency.

The reasons to continue statin therapy are more compelling in a patient with a recent coronary event (i.e., secondary prevention) than in a patient for whom the statin is prescribed for primary prevention. If the symptoms are mild but interfering with activity and quality of life, and the creatine kinase level is ≤5 times the upper limit of normal, a reasonable first step — informed by anecdotal evidence but not randomized trials — is to lower the dose or switch to another statin. Studies have found that at least half of patients who stop taking a statin because of adverse muscle effects are able to resume taking a statin. The hydrophilic statins (pravastatin and rosuvastatin) can be a good choice for a replacement when patients have myalgias while taking a lipophilic statin.

Key learning point: In a patient with coronary artery disease who is taking a high dose of a statin and has mild myalgias with a mildly increased creatine kinase level, the appropriate treatment is to lower the dose or switch to a different statin.

D) INCORRECT:

The evidence supporting secondary preventive benefit is more robust for statins than for other lipid-lowering drugs; hence, switching to another drug class such as ezetimibe is a less desirable initial approach in this patient. If a rechallenge with a statin is unsuccessful, then either ezetimibe or an inhibitor of proprotein convertase subtilisin-kexin type 9 serine protease (PCSK9) such as evolocumab or alirocumab would be other options, but only after attempting to resume statin therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Because this patient’s indication for statin therapy is compelling, stopping entirely and remeasuring lipids at a future date is suboptimal. However, statins should be stopped at least temporarily if the symptoms are severe, the creatine kinase level is at least 5 times the upper limit of normal, or there is renal impairment.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man with a history of stage 1 hypertension and obesity presents for follow-up related to his blood pressure and lipid levels. He currently takes no medications. He is 180 cm tall, weighs 107 kg, and has a BMI of 33. His blood pressure is 138/86 mm Hg. His father and one brother had myocardial infarctions at ages 51 and 52, respectively. During the past year, he has tried to adopt a low-fat diet and increase his exercise level, but he has had minimal success.
His fasting morning laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Glucose (mg/dL)
90
70–100


Glycated hemoglobin (%)
5.6
4.3–5.6


Total cholesterol (mg/dL)
213
—


LDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
126
—


HDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
35
—


Triglycerides (mg/dL)
260
—


The patient’s estimated 10-year risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease is 9.0% according to the risk calculator of the American College of Cardiology and American Heart Association.
Which one of the following medications is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient has a mild-to-moderate elevation of his triglyceride level; fibrate drugs (e.g., gemfibrozil, fenofibrate) can lower triglyceride levels to a greater degree than statins. However, statin therapy constitutes first-line lipid-lowering therapy in primary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. Fibrate therapy (primarily to reduce risk of pancreatitis) would be appropriate if the patient’s elevation in triglycerides was severe (e.g., >500 mg/dL).

B) INCORRECT:

Metformin has been shown to slow the rate at which patients with impaired fasting glucose and impaired glucose tolerance progress to meeting formal criteria for diabetes. Metformin is not indicated in a patient with a normal fasting blood-glucose level.

C) CORRECT:

The American College of Cardiology (ACC) and the American Heart Association (AHA) have identified four groups of patients for whom the benefits of statin therapy outweigh the risks in terms of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD):

• Patients with clinical ASCVD (secondary prevention)
• Patients with LDL-cholesterol levels ≥190 mg/dL
• Patients aged 40 to 75 years with diabetes mellitus
• Patients aged 40 to 75 years without diabetes mellitus who have LDL-cholesterol levels between 70 mg/dL and 189 mg/dL with an estimated 10-year risk for ASCVD of ≥7.5%

This patient fits into the fourth group and is therefore a candidate for statin therapy. Because his estimated 10-year risk of ASCVD is 9.0% (based on the ACC/AHA risk calculator), a moderate-intensity statin such as 40 mg of simvastatin is a reasonable choice; the 10-mg dose is considered low intensity.

Although family history is not included in the ACC/AHA risk calculator, this patient’s strong family history of early myocardial infarction adds weight to the decision to prescribe a statin. The most recent (2018) ACC/AHA cholesterol-lowering guidelines recommend using ASCVD risk enhancers, such as family history of premature ASCVD, chronic kidney disease, and South Asian ethnicity, to permit further risk stratification. We acknowledge, however, that some people have challenged the ACC/AHA guideline and risk calculator, arguing that they result in excessive treatment with statins for primary prevention of ASCVD in some nondiabetic patients.

In addition, the latest (2022) guidelines from the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force provide a grade C recommendation for prescribing statin therapy for primary prevention of CVD in individuals aged 40 to 75 years who have at least one CVD risk factor (e.g., dyslipidemia, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, smoking) plus an estimated 10-year ASCVD risk of 7.5% to 10%. The recommendation is upgraded to grade B if the estimated 10-year ASCVD risk is >10%.

Key learning point: According to current guidelines from the American College of Cardiology and the American Heart Association (ACC/AHA), patients without diabetes mellitus or clinical atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) who have LDL-cholesterol levels between 70 and 189 mg/dL should be offered statin therapy if their estimated 10-year risk of ASCVD is ≥7.5%.

D) INCORRECT:

Given that this patient does not have diabetes mellitus, known cardiovascular disease, or a 10-year risk of ASCVD ≥10%, current guidelines would recommend initiation of pharmacologic therapy for hypertension only if his blood pressure exceeded 140/90 mm Hg. Given his current blood pressure, it would be reasonable to recommend continued lifestyle changes to help reduce the blood pressure, but lisinopril is not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has a mild-to-moderate elevation of his triglyceride level; fibrate drugs (e.g., gemfibrozil, fenofibrate) can lower triglyceride levels to a greater degree than statins. However, statin therapy constitutes first-line lipid-lowering therapy in primary prevention of ASCVD. Fibrate therapy (primarily to reduce risk of pancreatitis) would be appropriate if the patient’s elevation in triglycerides was severe (e.g., >500 mg/dL).

questions.text:
A 59-year-old man presents with muscle pain and weakness. He reports that he fell unexpectedly about 4 weeks ago and had trouble getting up from the floor. He feels that his legs have been getting weaker since then, and he now has difficulty standing up from a seated position and going up and down stairs. He has had no diplopia, dysarthria, or dysphagia. He has no constitutional symptoms, although he notes that he recently had an upper respiratory tract infection that has resolved. He reports no sensory changes, bowel dysfunction, or bladder dysfunction.
His medical history is notable for hyperlipidemia, coronary artery disease, and recent myocardial infarction. He has been taking amlodipine, aspirin, metoprolol, and simvastatin, and recently added gemfibrozil.
Physical examination reveals proximal arm and leg weakness. His creatine kinase level is 14,000 U/liter (reference range, 60–400).
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s muscle weakness?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Myotoxicity is a known adverse effect of statin therapy. The median onset is 4 weeks after statin initiation, but symptoms may develop at any time, even in patients who have previously tolerated statin therapy. Complications range from mild myalgia to rhabdomyolysis to autoimmune necrotizing myopathy. New onset of myalgia, proximal weakness, and creatine kinase elevation in a patient with hyperlipidemia and cardiovascular disease should prompt detailed questioning about statin use and any recent dose adjustments or newly initiated medications.

The risk for statin-induced myopathy increases with factors that affect hepatic clearance, including liver dysfunction, concomitant use of medications that compete for or inhibit CYP3A4 (including macrolide antibiotics, systemic azole antifungals, cyclosporine, and HIV and hepatitis C protease inhibitors), and concomitant use of fibrates such as gemfibrozil, which was recently started in this patient. Other risk factors for statin-induced myopathy include alcohol use disorder, renal dysfunction, hypothyroidism, low BMI, female sex, and a personal or family history of statin intolerance.

Key learning point: New onset of myalgia, proximal weakness, and creatine kinase elevation in a patient with hyperlipidemia and cardiovascular disease should prompt detailed questioning about statin use.

B) INCORRECT:

Trauma related to this patient’s reported fall could have aggravated a preexisting cervical myelopathy; however, in such circumstances, one would expect sensory loss, bowel or bladder dysfunction, and a normal or only mildly elevated creatine kinase level.

C) INCORRECT:

Classic Guillain-Barré syndrome causes ascending weakness and numbness of the limbs over the course of days to weeks, with areflexia and autonomic involvement, and may progress to respiratory failure. The creatine kinase level is typically normal.

D) INCORRECT:

Inclusion-body myositis (IBM), the most common inflammatory myopathy in patients older than age 50, causes slowly progressive weakness over the course of years, particularly involving the quadriceps and finger flexors. Dysphagia may also occur. In patients with IBM, creatine kinase is usually only mildly elevated.

E) INCORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis rarely manifests with pure proximal muscle weakness. More commonly, patients have ocular or bulbar symptoms early in the disease. Elevation of creatine kinase is not a feature of myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man presents with muscle pain and weakness. He fell unexpectedly about 4 weeks ago and reports his legs have been getting weaker since then, with difficulty standing up from a seated position and going up and down stairs. He has had no diplopia, dysarthria, or dysphagia. He has no constitutional symptoms, although he notes that he recently had an upper respiratory tract infection that has resolved. He reports no sensory changes, bowel dysfunction, or bladder dysfunction. His medical history is notable for hyperlipidemia, coronary artery disease, and recent myocardial infarction. He has been taking amlodipine, aspirin, metoprolol, and simvastatin, and recently added gemfibrozil. Physical examination reveals proximal arm and leg weakness. His creatine kinase level is increased. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s muscle weakness?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Myotoxicity is a known adverse effect of statin therapy. The median onset is 4 weeks after statin initiation, but symptoms may develop at any time, even in patients who have previously tolerated statin therapy. Complications range from mild myalgia to rhabdomyolysis to autoimmune necrotizing myopathy. New onset of myalgia, proximal weakness, and creatine kinase elevation in a patient with hyperlipidemia and cardiovascular disease should prompt detailed questioning about statin use and any recent dose adjustments or newly initiated medications.

The risk for statin-induced myopathy increases with factors that affect hepatic clearance, including liver dysfunction, concomitant use of medications that compete for or inhibit CYP3A4 (including macrolide antibiotics, systemic azole antifungals, cyclosporine, and HIV and hepatitis C protease inhibitors), and concomitant use of fibrates such as gemfibrozil, which was recently started in this patient. Other risk factors for statin-induced myopathy include alcohol use disorder, renal dysfunction, hypothyroidism, low BMI, female sex, and a personal or family history of statin intolerance.

Key learning point: New onset of myalgia, proximal weakness, and creatine kinase elevation in a patient with hyperlipidemia and cardiovascular disease should prompt detailed questioning about statin use.

B) INCORRECT:

Trauma related to this patient’s reported fall could have aggravated a preexisting cervical myelopathy; however, in such circumstances, one would expect sensory loss, bowel or bladder dysfunction, and a normal or only mildly elevated creatine kinase level.

C) INCORRECT:

Classic Guillain-Barré syndrome causes ascending weakness and numbness of the limbs over days to weeks, with areflexia and autonomic involvement, and may progress to respiratory failure. The creatine kinase level is typically normal.

D) INCORRECT:

Inclusion-body myositis (IBM), the most common inflammatory myopathy in patients > 50 years of age, causes slowly progressive weakness over years, particularly involving the quadriceps and finger flexors. Dysphagia may also occur. In patients with IBM, creatine kinase is usually only mildly elevated.

E) INCORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis rarely manifests with pure proximal muscle weakness. Patients more commonly have ocular or bulbar symptoms in the early stages of the disease. Furthermore, elevation of creatine kinase is not a feature of myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the office for an annual health maintenance examination. He has a history of stable angina, gout, and hypertension. His medications include lisinopril and aspirin. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. He drinks 5–6 beers on the weekends. His blood pressure is 150/85 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show a total cholesterol of 276 mg/dL with an elevated low-density lipoprotein (LDL) concentration and low high-density lipoprotein (HDL) concentration. In addition to dietary and lifestyle modifications, administration of which of the following agents is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Niacin (vitamin B3) is a lipid-lowering agent that is synthesized from tryptophan. It decreases hepatic very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) synthesis, inhibits the activity of hormone-sensitive lipase, increases HDL levels, and, to a lesser degree, reduces triglyceride and LDL synthesis. Niacin is not, however, first-line monotherapy in patients with hyperlipidemia. Furthermore, it is not recommended in patients with gout because of the associated risk of hyperuricemia.

B) CORRECT:

Statins are first-line treatment for hyperlipidemia. Statins inhibit the conversion of HMG-CoA to mevalonate, thereby decreasing cholesterol synthesis in the liver. Statins are the most effective drug for reducing LDL levels, and they also increase HDL and lower triglyceride levels. Common side effects of HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors include elevated LFTs and myalgias (especially when used with fibrates).

Key learning point: Statins are the first-line pharmacologic therapy for hyperlipidemia due to their effectiveness in lowering LDL cholesterol and reducing cardiovascular risk.

C) INCORRECT:

Fibrates (e.g., bezafibrate, fenofibrate) activate peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (PPAR-α). The activation of PPAR-α increases lipoprotein lipase production, fatty acid uptake and oxidation, as well as HDL synthesis. Fibrates effectively decrease triglyceride levels and increase HDL levels, and only have a mild effect on LDL levels. Therefore, fibrates are not appropriate as monotherapy for this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Ezetimibe, a cholesterol absorption inhibitor, decreases LDL levels by inhibiting cholesterol absorption at the brush borders of the small intestine. However, ezetimibe is a second-line lipid-lowering agent and is reserved for patients who do not tolerate first-line therapy. Side effects of ezetimibe include diarrhea and increased LFTs.

E) INCORRECT:

Cholestyramine, a bile acid resin, lowers plasma LDL levels by binding to bile acid, thereby preventing bile acid reabsorption in the gastrointestinal tract and increasing intestinal LDL losses. Bile acid resins are not first-line therapy for hyperlipidemia because they have gastrointestinal side effects (e.g., diarrhea) and only lower LDL levels minimally.
questions.hint: This patient has hyperlipidemia and a history that suggests coronary artery disease (stable angina).

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man comes to your clinic for an annual health maintenance examination. He has a history of stable angina, gout, and hypertension. His medications are lisinopril and aspirin. He has a 20-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. He drinks 5–6 beers on weekends. His blood pressure is 150/85 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show a total cholesterol of 7.1 mmol/L (3.5–5.2), a low-density lipoprotein level (LDL) of 4.6 mmol/L, and a high-density lipoprotein level (HDL) of 0.9 mmol/L (>1.0).
Low-Density Lipoprotein (LDL) Analysis


Cardiovascular Disease Risk
When to Consider Initiating Treatment
Treatment Target



High and intermediate
LDL level of ≥ 3.5 mmol/L
LDL level of < 2.0 mmol/L or ≥50% reduction in pretherapy LDL level


Low
LDL level of > 5.0 mmol/L
≥50% reduction in pretherapy LDL level



In addition to dietary and lifestyle modifications, which one of the following agents is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fibrates (e.g., bezafibrate, fenofibrate) activate peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (PPAR-α). The activation of PPAR-α increases lipoprotein lipase production, fatty acid uptake and oxidation, as well as HDL synthesis. Fibrates effectively decrease triglyceride levels and increase HDL levels, and only have a mild effect on LDL levels. Therefore, fibrates are not appropriate as monotherapy for this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Niacin (vitamin B3) is a lipid-lowering agent that is synthesized from tryptophan. It decreases hepatic very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) synthesis, inhibits the activity of hormone-sensitive lipase, increases HDL levels, and, to a lesser degree, reduces triglyceride and LDL synthesis. Niacin is not, however, first-line monotherapy in patients with hyperlipidemia. Furthermore, it is not recommended in patients with gout because of the associated risk of hyperuricemia.

C) CORRECT:

Statins are first-line treatment for hyperlipidemia. Statins inhibit the conversion of HMG-CoA to mevalonate, thereby decreasing cholesterol synthesis in the liver. Statins are the most effective drug for reducing LDL levels, and they also increase HDL and lower triglyceride levels. Common side effects of HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors include elevated LFTs and myalgias (especially when used with fibrates).

Key learning point: Statins are the first-line pharmacologic therapy for hyperlipidemia because they most effectively lower LDL cholesterol and also improve HDL and triglyceride levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Cholestyramine, a bile acid resin, lowers plasma LDL levels by binding to bile acid, thereby preventing bile acid reabsorption in the gastrointestinal tract and increasing intestinal LDL losses. Bile acid resins are not first-line therapy for hyperlipidemia because they have gastrointestinal side effects (e.g., diarrhea) and only lower LDL levels minimally.

E) INCORRECT:

Ezetimibe, a cholesterol absorption inhibitor, decreases LDL levels by inhibiting cholesterol absorption at the brush borders of the small intestine. However, ezetimibe is a second-line lipid-lowering agent and is reserved for patients who do not tolerate first-line therapy. Side effects of ezetimibe include diarrhea and increased LFTs.
questions.hint: This patient has hyperlipidemia and a history that suggests coronary artery disease (stable angina).

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the last 15 years. Current medications include glyburide and amlodipine. The physician prescribes a medication that decreases the production of mevalonate. Which of the following changes to the serum is most likely to develop as an adverse effect of the prescribed drug?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Muscle-related adverse effects can develop within weeks to months after starting statin therapy. Statins can decrease the synthesis of coenzyme Q10 and impair energy production within muscle, which can result in myalgia, muscle weakness, and increased serum creatine kinase (CK) concentrations due to myositis and/or rhabdomyolysis.

Strategies to prevent muscle-related adverse effects related to statin therapy include the use of the lowest effective dose to reach target lipid goals and avoidance of drugs that can increase the risk of developing myopathies, such as fibrates, niacin, cyclosporine, and glucocorticoids. Muscle-related adverse effects typically resolve upon discontinuation of the drug.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient takes glyburide, a sulfonylurea that can cause hypoglycemia. However, statin therapy usually does not affect serum glucose concentrations.

C) INCORRECT:

Statin therapy usually does not affect serum lactate concentrations. Lactic acidosis is a rare but serious adverse effect of metformin therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Statin therapy lowers serum triglyceride concentrations by 10–20%. Drugs that commonly increase serum triglyceride concentrations include beta blockers, glucocorticoids, cyclosporine, and some HIV antiretroviral drugs.

E) INCORRECT:

Statin therapy usually does not affect serum bradykinin concentrations. The kinin pathway is altered by ACE inhibitors, which increase serum bradykinin concentrations and can result in adverse effects such as cough and angioedema.
questions.hint: This patient has been prescribed a statin as part of a primary prevention strategy for hyperlipidemia. Statins reduce serum cholesterol concentrations by preventing the conversion of HMG-CoA to mevalonate, which is a precursor of cholesterol.
